title: Sources
text:
Lightcast — AI-related job postings data (2014–2023)

U.S. Census Bureau

American Community Survey (ACS, 5‑year estimates 2013–2022) for demographics

Local Area Unemployment Statistics (LAUS, 2013–2023) for employment counts

Quarterly Workforce Indicators (QWI, 2013–2023) for labor turnover

County Business Patterns (CBP, 2013–2023) for establishment sizes & industry employment


Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA) — House Price Index & growth rates (2013–2024)

USPTO / PatentsView

All patents & inventor counts, by county

AI-specific patent classification (Giczy et al., 2022)


Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS) — Bachelor’s & master’s degrees awarded per capita

Code & Reproducibility

GitHub Repository: https://github.com/JacobKhay/AI-shares — all data‐prep, analysis, and Quarto site source

Quarto Site: your published site URL (e.g. https://yourusername.github.io/AI-shares/)

text:

tidyverse, fixest, modelsummary, kableExtra

sf, leaflet, tigris, scales

title: About
text:
Hello! I’m Jacob Khaykin
I’m a rising senior at Solon High School with a passion for data analysis and its real‑world applications. Currently, I’m exploring data science through dedicated coursework and hands‑on projects.

📧 Email: jacobkhaykin27@solonschools.net
💻 GitHub: AI‑shares
🎓 Bootcamp: David Kane’s Data Science Bootcamp

title: Interactive AI Job Share Map
text:
Have you ever wondered which U.S. counties lead in AI‑related job postings? This interactive map highlights both the average AI share over 2018‑2023 and the percentage‑point change since 2017‑2018.

Average AI Share shows where AI roles are most concentrated today.

Change in AI Share reveals the fastest‑growing hotspots of remote‑friendly AI jobs.

Toggle between layers to explore regional patterns and see how traditional tech hubs compare with emerging counties.








Map Takeaways: Even outside Silicon Valley, some unexpected corners of America—like Slope County (ND) and Maries County (MO)—have AI roles making up over 5–10% of all job ads. Meanwhile, many rural and industrial counties remain below 1%. Between 2018 and 2023, suburban and remote‑friendly regions saw the fastest growth, underscoring how AI work is decoupling from traditional tech hubs. This uneven landscape highlights both the promise of remote work and the risk that smaller communities could be left behind in the AI economy.
